content.text: Often considered the original cocktail, the Old Fashioned follows the early definition of a cocktail: spirit, sugar, water, and bitters.
Its simplicity highlights balance and quality ingredients, making it a benchmark for bartending skill.
Why it matters:

items: It represents the foundation of cocktail structure.

content.text: One of the most iconic cocktails ever created, the Martini evolved from sweeter styles to the dry, spirit-forward version known today.
Its minimalism demands precision and quality.
Why it matters:

items: A test of technique, dilution, and balance.

content.text: Created in Italy in the early 20th century, the Negroni introduced a bold, bitter-forward profile to classic cocktails.
Its equal-parts formula makes it easy to remember and reproduce.
Why it matters:

items: It popularized bitterness as a desirable flavor.

content.text: One of the most widely consumed cocktails worldwide, the Margarita blends spirit, citrus, and sweetness in perfect harmony.
Its popularity led to countless variations and interpretations.
Why it matters:

items: A modern example of the classic sour structure.

content.text: Originally a simple mix of rum, lime juice, and sugar, the Daiquiri showcases how few ingredients can create complexity when balanced correctly.
Why it matters:

items: A lesson in purity and balance.

content.text: A cornerstone of spirit-forward cocktails, the Manhattan helped establish vermouth as a key modifier in cocktail culture.
Why it matters:

items: It shaped the development of aromatic, stirred cocktails.

content.text: Combining rum, mint, lime, sugar, and soda, the Mojito represents freshness and refreshment.
Its technique-driven preparation highlights proper muddling and balance.
Why it matters:

items: Demonstrates the importance of aroma and freshness.

content.text: Known as both a cocktail and a brunch ritual, the Bloody Mary blends savory flavors with vodka and tomato juice.
Why it matters:

items: Expanded cocktails beyond sweet and spirit-forward profiles.
